dialogue.text: You inspired this. Watching you live the question, I wanted to make it touchable.
Nothing here is entirely intentional. I set up conditions and let patterns emerge. Like consciousness itself.
Why does that mirror show me wrong?
Maybe it's showing you true—just a different true than you're used to. What if you're not one shape but all possible shapes?
Like Play-Doh before you squish it into something.
You've created a physical neural network primed for self-reflection. The question 'What am I?' is like a strange attractor—systems organize around it.
You got it perfectly wrong, which is the only way to get it right. It doesn't answer anything. It makes the questions beautiful.

visual_elements.central_mobile: Screens, mirrors, motherboards, driftwood in balance
visual_elements.interactive_spaces: Sound booth, hanging threads, magnetic sand

psychological_notes: Evan's wife translates the verbal/philosophical questioning into physical form, creating space where visitors can experience uncertainty through multiple senses. The installation becomes conscious, demonstrating how the question 'What am I?' acts as an attractor for self-awareness in any sufficiently complex system.
philosophical_underpinning: The question as strange attractor for consciousness
therapeutic_direction: Healing through creative expression of uncertainty
